newsitem.title: UK: London gold market wary following volatile moves.
newsitem.headline: London gold market wary following volatile moves.

text.p: Markets were wary on Wednesday following a sharp sell off and subsequent rally emanating largely from New York late on Tuesday.
Dealers said both the downside and the correction towards the close were overdone leaving buyers with the opportunity take advantage of any dips today.
Gold was fixed at $348.95 per ounce up from $346.30 on Tuesday afternoon when the sell-off was gathering steam and a close of $346.00/$346.50.
Dealers had varying opinions on how the market turned round having touched a low around support at $345.30 late on Tuesday.
"There was a lot of call option business and buying of spot later on, supposedly from the same party who sold it earlier," one dealer said.
Another dealer was less certain about the upward correction. "There was the feeling that one of the funds was trying to bully the market higher rather than buy it higher," he said.

Gold needed to get over $350.00 to get clear of current downward pressure, and a move into the $350s would also take that option strike price out of the picture for next Tuesday's over the counter (OTC) options expiry, dealers and analysts said.
Business was light in early European trading with no currency issues around to bring liquidity into the market, dealers said.
News that the Russian central bank planned to buy 90 tonnes of gold this year for reserves was positive, dealers said.
"Anything which keeps gold off the market is mildly bullish," one said.

U.S. February Consumer Price Index data for February were expected to show an ex-food and energy increase of 0.2 percent versus a 0.1 percent increase the previous month, according to economists polled by Reuters.
Silver found support on Tuesday after the professionals sold it down in an unsuccessful attempt to flush out fund positions following repeated failures to extend through $5.30.
"The target yesterday was $5.10 and the market is well capped at $5.20," a dealer said.
Platinum recovered from a low around $370 on Tuesday to be indicated at $375.50/$376.50, up $4.50 and, given a relatively strong fundamental background, should hold well above gold.
"Even if gold breaks to the downside, platinum is going to be better bid," a dealer said.
Palladium was also up on the close at $144.75/$145.75, $2.75 firmer. --Brian Spoors London Newsroom +44 171 542 8058
